definition: The percentage of callers who hang up before reaching a live agent, reflecting hold-time management and IVR design effectiveness.
The process of re-engaging website visitors who begin but do not complete a booking, typically through triggered emails or retargeting ads.
Total room revenue divided by the number of rooms sold; a key hotel performance metric.
An OTA business model where the hotel sets the rate, the guest pays the hotel, and the OTA earns a commission on the completed stay.
Systematic errors or unfair outcomes in AI systems resulting from biased training data or model design.
A pre-agreed block of rooms allocated to a wholesaler for a specific period, with unsold rooms reverting to the hotel after a cutoff date.
Lodging options outside the traditional hotel model, including vacation rentals, serviced apartments, hostels, and hybrid concepts.
Non-room revenue generated by a hotel guest, including food and beverage, spa, parking, resort fees, and other on-property spending.
A set of protocols that allows different software systems to communicate and exchange data.
A business model in which the company does not own the physical assets (properties) it distributes, instead earning fees or commissions from transactions.
The process of determining which marketing or distribution touchpoints deserve credit for generating a booking or conversion.
The shortfall between the number of rooms blocked for a group and the number actually booked by attendees.
A contractual provision requiring the group to compensate the hotel for rooms in the block that go unbooked beyond an agreed threshold.
Technology that routes incoming calls to the most appropriate agent based on predefined criteria such as caller profile, language, and inquiry type.
A transaction model where a company sells products or services to other businesses rather than directly to consumers.
A distribution model where a company sells through business intermediaries who then sell to end consumers
The lowest unrestricted retail rate available to consumers through the hotel's direct channels.
A wholesale aggregator that contracts large volumes of hotel inventory at net rates and redistributes to downstream B2B partners.
A hotel's promise that the lowest publicly available rate is found on its direct booking channels.
The process (often automated) of setting and optimizing CPC or CPA bids across metasearch platforms.
The hypothesis that a hotel's listing on an OTA generates incremental awareness and traffic to the hotel's own website, resulting in direct bookings.
A decentralized, distributed digital ledger technology that records transactions across multiple computers in a way that is transparent and resistant to modification.
The e-commerce software on a hotel's website that enables guests to search availability and complete reservations.
A hotel brand's proprietary website used as a direct booking channel.
Tools and platforms that aggregate, analyze, and visualize data from multiple systems to support decision-making.
A centralized facility operated by a hotel brand or management company that handles telephone reservations across multiple properties.
A centralized system that manages hotel inventory, rates, and reservations across all distribution channels.
Technology that synchronizes inventory and rates across multiple distribution channels in real time.
The proportional blend of bookings from different distribution channels.
The phenomenon in which a guest who would have booked through a lower-cost channel instead books through a higher-cost channel.
The behavior of guests who begin their booking journey on one channel (e.g., the hotel website) and complete it on another (e.g., voice or messaging).
A large-scale event that exceeds the capacity of any single hotel, requiring room blocks across multiple properties in a destination, typically coordinated by a CVB or housing bureau.
A defined group of users who receive access to rates not available to the general public.
Software designed from the ground up to run in cloud environments, using modern architectures like microservices and APIs.
A credit card issued in partnership between a hotel company and a financial institution, allowing cardholders to earn loyalty points on everyday purchases.
A percentage of the booking value paid to an intermediary for facilitating a reservation.
The number of complimentary room nights provided relative to paid room nights in a group contract (e.g., 1:40 or 1:50).
The group of properties against which a hotel benchmarks its performance; increasingly includes short-term rental supply in addition to comparable hotels.
A technology design approach in which applications are built from modular, interchangeable components that communicate through standardized interfaces.
An approach where hotels assemble best-of-breed technology components from different vendors, connected via open APIs.
Booking Holdings' strategy to bundle multiple travel products into a single, integrated booking experience.
A technology company (e.g., Derbysoft, SiteMinder) that manages the technical connection between hotels and metasearch platforms
A marketing strategy focused on creating and distributing valuable, relevant content to attract and retain a target audience.
A fixed wholesale net rate negotiated in advance for a defined period.
A destination marketing organization that promotes a city or region as a meetings and events destination.
A search paradigm in which users interact with AI systems through natural language dialogue rather than keyword queries.
The percentage of reservation-intent calls that result in a confirmed booking.
The systematic process of increasing the percentage of website visitors who complete a desired action, such as making a booking.
The total expenses associated with acquiring a booking through a given channel.
A bidding model where the advertiser pays a percentage of booking value only on confirmed reservations.
A bidding model where the advertiser pays each time a user clicks on their listing.
A system that collects and organizes guest data to enable personalized marketing, service, and loyalty management.
A self-reinforcing cycle in which guest data from direct bookings enables personalized marketing, driving higher loyalty and more direct bookings.
An enterprise-level system that manages rate and inventory distribution across all channels and delivers reservations to properties.
A projection of the total net revenue a hotel can expect from a single guest over the entire duration of their relationship.
The deadline by which group attendees must book rooms to receive the negotiated group rate.
The leading technology platform for meetings and events sourcing, management, and analytics.
A reservation made directly with the hotel without an intermediary.
A booking pathway where the transaction occurs directly between guest and hotel.
An analytical framework evaluating whether accepting a group booking at a negotiated rate generates more total revenue than the transient demand it would displace.
A market structure dominated by two firms; in the OTA context, Booking Holdings and Expedia Group.
The practice of adjusting prices in real time based on demand, competition, and other market signals.
A wholesale net rate derived in real-time from the hotel's BAR using a pre-agreed discount formula.
A loyalty program pricing model where the points required for a free night vary based on demand.
Tiered recognition within a loyalty program earned through qualifying stays or spending, unlocking escalating benefits.
Guest attachment to a brand driven by positive experiences, personal connection, and trust — beyond economic incentives.
A framework for evaluating a company's sustainability and ethical practices in hospitality investment and operations.
A software design pattern where systems communicate by publishing and subscribing to events (e.g., "reservation created") rather than polling for changes.
Loyalty program benefits offering unique experiences rather than traditional room-night redemptions.
An individual traveler booking through the wholesale channel, as opposed to a group.
Unpaid hotel listings in Google's booking module, launched in 2021, available to any hotel with a connectivity partner.
Electronic platform connecting travel suppliers with travel agents and corporate buyers (e.g., Amadeus, Sabre, Travelport).
Artificial intelligence systems capable of creating original content based on patterns learned from training data.
Strategies for ensuring a brand's information is accurately represented in AI-generated content and recommendations.
Booking.com's tiered loyalty program offering discounts to frequent users, funded by participating hotels.
Google Hotel Ads Commission Program — commission charged only on completed (stayed) bookings
Commission charged only on completed (stayed) bookings through Google Hotel Ads.
Google's advertising product that displays hotel prices within Search, Maps, and Google Travel.
The total dollar value of bookings processed through a platform, before deducting the platform's fees and commissions. Distinct from *revenue*, which reflects only the platform's retained share.
A set number of rooms held under a single contract at a negotiated rate for a group event.
The historical pattern by which groups pick up fewer rooms than originally blocked; used as a forecasting adjustment to improve inventory management.
An international body that establishes and manages global standards for sustainable travel and tourism.
The average duration of a reservation call from greeting to completion, including hold time and after-call work. A key efficiency metric for call center operations.
An organization, often affiliated with a CVB, that manages centralized room-block allocation and attendee reservations for large conventions across multiple hotels.
An OTA business model combining elements of both agency and merchant approaches.
The percentage of eligible searches in which a hotel's metasearch ad appeared; a measure of visibility and missed opportunity
The measurement of whether a marketing channel drives truly new bookings versus capturing demand that would have occurred anyway.
A booking pathway involving one or more third-party intermediaries.
A marketing strategy partnering with individuals who have significant social media followings to promote products or services.
An emerging capability allowing meeting planners to book group rooms and meeting space online in real time without the traditional RFP process.
An automated telephony system that interacts with callers through voice prompts and keypad inputs.
A network of physical devices embedded with sensors, software, and connectivity, enabling data collection and remote control.
The information box Google displays for a hotel, including photos, reviews, location, and booking options.
The percentage of visitors arriving at a hotel's website from a metasearch click who complete a booking; the most critical variable in CPC metasearch economics
A type of AI model trained on vast amounts of text data, capable of understanding and generating human-like text.
See Customer Lifetime Value (CLV).
A structured marketing program that rewards guests for repeat patronage through points, elite status, and exclusive benefits.
A discounted room rate available exclusively to loyalty program members who book through direct channels.
An OTA business model where the OTA purchases inventory at a net rate and resells it at a markup, collecting payment from the guest.
A platform that aggregates prices from multiple booking sources for comparison (e.g., Google Hotel Ads, Kayak, Trivago).
An architectural approach where a software application is built as a collection of small, independent services, each handling a specific function and communicating via APIs.
Software that acts as a bridge between different applications, translating data formats and routing information between systems that were not originally designed to work together.
A contractual clause requiring hotels to offer the OTA a rate no higher than the rate on the hotel's own direct channels.
A confidential wholesale rate given to intermediaries, who add their own markup before selling to consumers.
RevPAR minus distribution costs; a measure of true channel profitability.
The end-of-day process of reconciling a hotel's financial transactions, traditionally run overnight.
A regulatory limit on the number of nights per year a property may be rented on a short-term basis.
A tax levied on short-term accommodation guests, historically applied to hotels and increasingly extended to short-term rentals.
A revenue management strategy in which each room type, channel, and segment can be priced independently.
A third-party online platform that sells hotel rooms to consumers (e.g., Booking.com, Expedia).
The fee paid by a hotel to an online travel agency for each booking, typically 15–25% of room revenue.
The proprietary formula used by an OTA to determine the order in which hotels appear in search results.
The practice of optimizing a hotel's OTA listing to improve ranking position.
Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard — security standards to protect credit card data during processing and storage.

term: PCI DSS (Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard)
definition: Security standards designed to protect credit card data during processing and storage.
The practice of tailoring marketing, service, and offerings to individual guests based on their data profile and behavior.
The core operational software managing reservations, check-in/out, guest profiles, billing, and housekeeping.
The financial obligation a hotel company carries on its balance sheet representing the estimated future cost of redeeming outstanding loyalty points.
A specialist firm, prevalent in Europe and Asia, that manages the end-to-end logistics of conferences and congresses, including venue sourcing, accommodation, and on-site operations.
An individual or company that manages multiple short-term rental properties as a business.

A composite metric used by metasearch platforms (notably Google and Trivago) reflecting rate accuracy, landing page experience, and expected conversion rate; higher scores improve ad positioning and reduce effective cost per click
An automated data connection transmitting real-time rates and availability from a hotel's systems to metasearch platforms.
The appearance of confidential wholesale net rates on consumer-facing booking channels.
A contractual obligation requiring a hotel to offer consistent pricing across distribution channels.
A competitive intelligence tool that monitors and compares hotel room rates across OTAs and competitor websites, providing data to inform pricing decisions.
The practice of monitoring a hotel's rates across multiple distribution channels to detect parity violations.
Exploiting differences in regulatory treatment between sectors (e.g., short-term rentals vs. licensed hotels).
The deadline by which a wholesaler must confirm bookings against an allotment; unsold rooms return to the hotel.
A formal document soliciting hotel proposals for a group event, specifying dates, room needs, and budget.
Serving digital ads to users who previously visited a website but did not convert.
The percentage of guests who return to stay at a hotel within a defined period.
The average revenue generated per incoming reservation call, factoring in conversion rate and booking value.
Total room revenue divided by total available rooms; the lodging industry's key performance metric.
Software that uses data and algorithms to optimize room pricing and inventory allocation.
A metric measuring revenue generated per dollar of advertising spend.
A software distribution model where applications are hosted in the cloud and accessed via subscription.
Paid advertising on search engines, primarily pay-per-click campaigns.
Improving a website's organic (unpaid) ranking in search engine results.
The final price at which a room is sold to the consumer after all intermediary markups.
An economic model based on peer-to-peer sharing of access to goods, services, or resources, typically facilitated by digital platforms.
An economic model based on peer-to-peer sharing of access to goods, services, or resources, typically facilitated by digital platforms.
A furnished residential property rented for short periods (typically less than 30 days), often through online platforms.
A call-routing methodology that directs callers to agents with specific expertise based on the caller's profile.
Social, Military, Educational, Religious, and Fraternal groups — a budget-conscious but reliable group subsegment.
The use of social media platforms to facilitate commercial transactions, including travel discovery and booking.
A collection within a major hotel chain allowing independent hotels to retain their identity while accessing the chain's distribution and loyalty systems.
A small per-transaction bonus paid to front desk or reservations agents for successful upsells, incentivizing sales behavior.
A loyalty structure where guests pay a recurring fee for guaranteed benefits.
A mobile application providing multiple services (messaging, payments, transport, travel) within a single platform.
The ability of accommodation supply to expand or contract in response to demand changes.
Technology layer that translates data between hotel CRS systems and GDS platforms.
Replacing sensitive payment data with non-sensitive substitute values (tokens) to reduce security risk.
Guest repeat behavior driven primarily by economic incentives rather than emotional attachment.
A professional providing personalized travel planning and booking services, earning commissions from suppliers.
A system connection that allows data to flow in both directions — for example, rates flowing out and reservations flowing back.
The integration of all commercial touchpoints into a single, seamless technology ecosystem.
Offering a guest a higher-value product or service than originally requested to increase total revenue per booking.
A single-use, system-generated credit card number used by OTAs and wholesalers to remit payment to hotels.
An aggregator that sources hotel inventory from multiple bed banks via API connections rather than contracting directly with hotels
Software that analyzes recorded calls to extract insights on agent performance, caller sentiment, conversion patterns, and quality assurance metrics.
A guest who arrives at a hotel without a prior reservation and requests to book a room on the spot.
A product or service produced by one company and rebranded by another to appear as its own
An intermediary that contracts hotel inventory in bulk at net rates for redistribution.
A contractual clause requiring hotels to offer the OTA a rate no higher than the rate available on any other distribution channel.
